metadata.title: Strain-controlled electrocatalysis on multimetallic nanomaterials

sections.text:
To reduce our reliance on fossil fuels and thus minimize our environmental impact, it is imperative to commit to clean and renewable energy innovation, which includes searching for clean and sustainable energy sources, transporting energy safely and economically, and converting energy efficiently at low cost1–6. Fuel cells are energyconverting devices powered by hydrogen, which have been long anticipated to replace conventional heat engines in automotive, residential, portable and other energy applications7–9. However, the widespread application of fuel cell technology is hampered by two limitations associated with the interfacial reactions that occur at the electrodes: the high overpotential induced by the sluggish kinetics renders the energy conversion efficiency far below the thermodynamic limit, especially for the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and the cost of the currently indispensable platinum-based electrocatalysts is prohibitively high for large-scale applications10–13. To overcome these limitations, it is necessary to develop more efficient electrocatalytic materials with higher reactivity than the commonly used carbonsupported platinum nanoparticles (Pt/C), because this would provide a higher working energy density and thus reduce the required amount of precious metal14,15. Considerable efforts have been devoted to bridging the activity gap and exploring advanced strategies in making Pt more catalytically active. Some of these strategies include alloying Pt with other transition metals16–18, forming a Pt skin or skeleton on the catalyst surface19–23, shaping Pt or Pt-based alloys24–26, and using multidimensional nanostructures27–31. There has been a dramatic improvement in the mass activity (that is, activity in terms of mass) of Pt-based nanocatalysts for the ORR in the past few years32; for example, typical Mo-doped PtNi octahedral nanoparticles now reach 6.98 A mgPt−1 (REF. 33). It is also important to understand the structure– performance relationship of multimetallic nanocrystals and to identify the factors that govern the catalytic activity, which can, in turn, facilitate the rational structural design of more active electrocatalysts34. For most typical Pt-based bimetallic catalytic systems (PtM, where M represents a transition metal), there are usually three structure-relevant factors that dominate the electrocatalytic performance, namely, the ensemble effect, ligand effect and strain effect35–37. Ensemble effects (or synergistic effects) are derived from the presence of Pt and M atoms (which have different mechanistic functionalities) on the surface of the catalyst. Ligand effects arise when the electronic structure of Pt is modified by a neighbouring M atom. By contrast, strain effects can alter the atomic spacing of surface Pt to tune the catalytic reactivity even when M atoms are buried at depths greater than 1 nm (REF. 35). Considering that M atoms on the surface or in the first few sub surface layers are easily etched away during electrochemical cycling, the role of the strain effect is more significant than the other two effects in fuel cell catalysis38.
The engineering of surface strain is of growing importance for optimizing the electrocatalytic activity of fuel cell-relevant reactions. In this Review, we showcase the advances in theoretical calculations and modelling as well as experimental methods that have furthered our fundamental understanding of the effect of surface strain on electrocatalysis (FIG. 1). First, we introduce the concept of surface strain, including the quantification of surface strain in nanomaterials, as well as classic modulation and characterization approaches. Then, we review experimental and theoretical studies that correlate the electrocatalytic activity with surface strain. Next, we discuss progress in strain-engineering electrocatalysis for the ORR on Pt-based and Pd-based nanomaterials according to the types of induced surface strain (that is, compressive strain and tensile strain). Finally, challenges associated with strain-engineering electrocatalytic nanomaterials are discussed, and a perspective of future research directions is provided.

sections.heading: Fundamental understanding of strain
sections.text:
Definition and quantification of surface strain Elastic strain is one of the most important physical properties for solid materials and is of fundamental importance in physics39, biology40 and chemistry41. Not surprisingly, many definitions exist to describe and quantify the observed elastic strain in different applications42. For electrocatalysis, focus has been placed on materials in nanoparticulate form (for the purpose of maximizing the active surface-to-volume ratio), whereby the absolute magnitude of the induced strain is very small. In this case, strain along a line is generally defined as (lf − li)/li, where li and lf represent the atomic bond length in the initial and final states, respectively43. However, experimentally, it is notoriously challenging to evaluate the atomic bond length accurately and statistically (that is, using a large number of samples), which drives researchers to develop alternative definitions.
In a given nanocrystal, strain-induced changes in the atomic bond length can be viewed as distortions of the corresponding bulk lattice. Such distortion is directly correlated with variations in the lattice parameters, which can then be readily detected by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements. Accordingly, the following equation was proposed to determine the lattice strain (s) on the surface of a catalytically active metal using an ideal core–shell structured nanoparticle as the model35:
s = ((ashell – abulk)/abulk) × 100 (1)
where ashell and abulk are the lattice parameters of the catalytic metal in the shell and in bulk form, respectively. Although equation 1 was initially proposed to
illustrate the surface strain induced by lattice mismatch (between the surface Pt and the substrate alloy), it can be extended to other nanocrystals with surface atoms that are either compressed or expanded with respect to the ideal bulk state. This generality makes equation 1 a powerful tool for quantifying the variations in lattice strain, offering great convenience in correlating the structural properties and surface reactivity of new electrocatalytic nanomaterials.

sections.heading: Modulation of surface strain
sections.text:
To benefit from strain modification, the question arises of how to introduce and modulate strain to a desired level on the surface of multimetallic materials. In fact, surface strain inherently exists on nanomaterials for two main reasons. First, compared with the inner atoms, the characteristic lower coordination or dangling bonds of surface atoms (the coordination numbers for typical low-index (111) or (100) facets are 9 or 8, respectively) typically results in the emergence of internal strain in an attempt to minimize the surface energy44. Second, nanocrystals should not be simply considered as small pieces of a bulk material. Unusual forms of structural disorder may exist and thus induce surface strain45. According to these factors, the surface strain tends to compress to a larger extent on nanocrystals with a smaller size. Such size-dependence has been widely observed46,47 and is not discussed further in this Review. Although it is reasonable to tune the surface strain by controlling the size of the nanomaterial, in practical electrocatalysis, this strategy is not very useful, because it is always desirable to make electrocatalysts as small as possible to maximize the surface/volume ratio and thus the atomic utilization. Therefore, efforts have been taken to tune the surface strain without compromising other structural properties. We divide these efforts into two categories: external-force induced and architecture induced.
Correlating induced strain with catalytic performance is of fundamental importance for the design and construction of highly efficient catalytic nanomaterials. Such a mechanistic study of the strain–performance relationship requires the capability of inducing surface strain on catalysts as precisely as possible, which can be achieved by exerting and controlling an external force on catalytic metals to induce the desired strain. To date, numerous approaches have been developed to tune the surface strain in catalytic materials through application of an external force, for example, by introducing subsurface inert gas (Ar or He) bubbles by low-energy inert ion bombardment48,49, physically bending or stretching the supporting substrate50,51, thermomechnically deforming a shape-memory alloy substrate52, and extracting and intercalating ions from a battery electrode support53.
Depositing catalytic metals on shape or volume tunable substrates has been a powerful strategy for precisely and continuously controlling the surface strain and thus is beneficial for the fundamental study of the strain effect. Taking advantage of the controllable twoway deformation of shape-memory alloys, NiTi sheets were used as substrates for engineering the surface strain (unstrained, compressively strained or tensilely strained)

A more interesting design to tune the surface strain of Pt nanoparticles from compressive to tensile was achieved using a common Li-ion battery electrode material (LiCoO2) as the support53 (FIG. 2a). LiCoO2 undergoes a large volume change when Li ions are repeatedly intercalated and extracted during electrochemical charge and discharge54,55. For a 5-nm-thick layer of Pt nanoparticles on the surface of LiCoO2 or Li0.5CoO2, compressive and tensile strains were found on Pt after the composites were subjected to charging and discharging in a battery pouch cell, respectively.
Progress in nanotechnology enables many opportunities for engineering the surface strain in a number of nanomaterials by manipulating the structural properties, such as the morphology, composition and architecture. Constructing a core–shell architecture is the most common way to induce surface strain, based on lattice mismatch, in electrocatalysts56–58. When two metals or alloys with different lattice parameters are in direct contact, lattice mismatch is generated at the interface and further leads to lattice distortion (that is, lattice strain) in each crystalline component59,60 (FIG. 2b). The lattice strain effect generally decays from the interface to the surface and thus influences the electrocatalytic process by modification of both the geometric and electronic structures. Numerous synthetic approaches have been reported to produce core–shell architectures, such as epitaxial growth61–63, surface dealloying22,64–66, galvanic replacement67–69 and surface segregation70,71.
Shaping nanomaterials with well-defined exposed surfaces is another way to control the surface strain. As the atoms located within the facets or at the edges or vertices of nanocrystals have very different coordination numbers, a large distribution of surface strains is expected72,73. In particular, for polycrystalline mat erials, we should
consider the role of multiple twinned boundaries separating two single-crystalline domains. Decahedra and icosahedra in face-centred-cubic (fcc) structures are typical twinned morphologies, with 15 and 30 twinned boundaries, respectively. Usually, very large strains exist along the boundaries because a twinned structure does not perfectly fill the volume that the atoms would typically occupy. It is worth noting that the surface strain is also susceptible to environmental factors (such as capping ligands, adsorbates and supporting effects), making the determination of strain in practical nanomaterials much more complicated than in ideal models.

sections.heading: Characterization techniques
sections.text:
Conventional techniques for detecting the surface strain in nanomaterials include atomic-resolution electron microscopy, scanning tunnelling microscopy, XRD and X-ray absorption spectroscopy74. However, these methods are mainly limited to either two or three dimensions with low spatial resolution75,76. To advance our understanding of the structure–functionality relationship, it is crucial to locate the 3D position of atoms with high precision, which requires more advanced characterization techniques and modelling methods. One such technique is electron tomography77,78. Recently, using a gold nanorod as the model structure, a methodology for mapping the high-resolution 3D strain field based on compressedsensing electron tomography was demonstrated79. By introducing an additional penalty parameter to minimize the projection error, 3D reconstructed strain mapping was obtained by geometrical phase analysis (FIG. 2c), which enabled the precise determination of the atomic positions. Electrochemical techniques have also been developed to probe the induced surface strain in metal nanocatalysts. sections.heading: Surface strain and electrocatalysis
sections.text:
By boosting the rates of electrochemical reactions, electrocatalysis can improve the operative efficiency of energy conversion and storage devices, such as fuel cells and metal–air batteries83,84. It is well established that the binding strength between the catalytic surface and the reaction intermediates governs the reaction rate. This binding strength is also referred to as the reaction descriptor. According to the Sabatier principle, plotting the measured activities as a function of the binding strength results in a volcano curve, which has been
experimentally confirmed in a number of heterogeneous reactions85–87. This correlation highlights the significance of designing catalytic materials with moderate binding strength, because either too strong or too weak binding to the reaction intermediates results in difficulty in removing the products or poor adsorption of the reactants88, respectively.
As the binding strength is closely related to the structural properties of catalytic materials, numerous studies have been conducted to determine the key structural factors affecting the catalytic activity. In 1983, the importance of interatomic spacing in the electroreduction of oxygen in acidic media was demonstrated89. In this early study, based on the dual-site mechanism of the ORR, it was proposed that an optimum atomic spacing exists at which a maximum catalytic activity is attained. To test this proposal, the specific ORR activities of various Pt-based alloy catalysts were plotted as a function of the corresponding atomic spacing (experimentally determined from XRD), showing a clear activity dependence on the atomic spacing. To the best of our knowledge, this represents the earliest attempt to correlate the observed reaction rates with the surface strain in catalytic nanomaterials. However, the discussion was mainly based on geometric considerations and was not clear on how surface strain affects the adsorption characteristics of a given catalyst.
This question was later addressed in 1998 in a seminal work in which the effect of strain on the reactivity of metal surfaces was attributed to a shift in the centre of the metal d bands90. According to the d-band model91, the position of the d-band centre has the determinant role in the adsorption energies and activation energy barriers. By comparing the adsorption and dissociation properties of strained and unstrained Ru(0001) surfaces, the following general trends were concluded: tensile lattice strain upshifts the d-band centre, thus causing a stronger interaction with adsorbates, whereas compressive strain downshifts the d-band centre, thus weakening the interaction. Until now, these trends have served as the fundamental link between the surface strain and the observed catalytic activity, as well as a guideline for the design of electrocatalytic materials by surface strain modification. We note that this trend is only applicable to the late transition metals (of which most catalytic materials are composed), in which the d bands are more than half filled. A recent study shows that early transition metals (ETMs) with a less than half-filled d band exhibit lower adsorption energies upon lattice expansion, in contrast to what is observed in typical late transition metals92. This apparent inconsistency can be explained on the basis of the classical d-band model. Specifically, an expanded surface strain can reduce the overlap of the wavefunctions and therefore narrow the metal d band. For late transition metals, the band narrowing results in an increased population of the d band, which upshifts the d-band centre to preserve the degree of d-band filling. For ETMs, the same mechanism downshifts the d-band centre (FIG. 3a,b).
The theoretical studies described above suggest that the electronic structure and thus the catalytic activity can be modified by managing the surface strain in a given catalytic material. This has been validated experimentally, whereby the surface strain of PtCo nanocatalysts was manipulated by controlling the atomic composition93. In this case, a more compressive strain resulted in a higher ORR activity. To show the descriptive role of surface strain in tuning the catalytic activity, a plot is shown in FIG. 3c of the specific activity and Pt–Pt bond length as a function of atomic composition, which yields two perfect linear correlations. Using a CuPt–Pt core–shell structure as the model, a compressive strain of 2.5% on the Pt shell correlated with the maximum ORR activity94. The compressively strained Pt nanoparticles showed a 52% enhancement in the kinetic rate constant over the unstrained nanoparticles (FIG. 3d), whereas the
tensilely strained nanoparticles had the opposite effect52. In another report, it was found that the ORR activity increased by 90% and decreased by 40% when the strain of a Pt surface was compressed and expanded by around 5%, respectively53. The same trend has also been observed in other studies using model electrocatalytic materials that can effectively eliminate the interference of other beneficial effects (such as ligand effects)95.

sections.heading: Strain-engineered electrocatalysts
sections.text: Studies involving density functional theory (DFT) calculations on model catalysts have proved the capability of surface strain to alter the d-band centre of catalytic metals and thus enhance the activity. This has stimulated considerable efforts to design promising nanostructures for different electrocatalytic applications through proper strain engineering. In this section, we selectively review recent progress on strain-engineered nanoelectro catalysts for the ORR according to the types of induced surface strain (that is, compressive strain and tensile strain).

sections.heading: Pt electrocatalysts with compressive surface strain
sections.text:
Pure Pt electrocatalysts. Recently, a jagged pure Pt nanowire electrocatalyst enclosed by a highly stressed, under-coordinated rhombohedral-rich surface was demonstrated to have world-record ORR mass and specific activities of 11.5 mA cm−2 and 13.6 A mgPt−1, respectively96. The generation of compressive surface strain on the jagged Pt nanowire is highly dependent on the synthetic procedure, which involves the initial synthesis of a Pt–NiO core–shell nanowire, subsequent conversion to a PtNi alloy nanowire by thermal annealing and finally transformation into a jagged Pt nanowire through electrochemical dealloying. The extremely high ORR activity was mainly attributed to the compressive strain because jagged Pt nanowires have a shorter Pt–Pt distance (2.70 Å) on the surface than regular Pt nanowires (2.76 Å) or bulk Pt crystals (2.77 Å). The promoting role of compressive strain in the enhancement of the ORR catalytic activity of the jagged Pt nanowire was further confirmed by a theoretical study based on first-principles multiscale simulations and DFT calculations97, which sought to rationalize the extraordinary ORR activity of the previously reported Pt3Ni7 catalyst98.
Core–shell electrocatalysts. Introducing transition metals with smaller atomic radii to create lattice mismatch is the most general strategy for inducing compressive surface strain on Pt. From a synthetic point of view, this can be achieved by constructing a core–shell structure, in which Pt serves as the shell and smaller transition metals (M or PtM alloys) serve as the core. To date, various Pt-based core–shell nanostructures have been realized25,57,99. Considering that the ligand effect from the transition metal may also contribute to the enhanced activity of core–shell electrocatalysts, especially in the case of an ultrathin Pt shell37,68, we focus on catalytic nanostructures for which the surface strain effect has the dominant role. Such materials include a dealloyed core–shell structure, a Pt shell on an intermetallic core and a Pt shell on an ETM.

Owing to differences in the oxidation potential, lessnoble transition metals can be selectively removed from the surface of an alloy nanostructure by chemical or electrochemical leaching. This process, which is also known as dealloying, normally results in either porous or solid core–shell nanostructures, which are determined by the competition between the surface dissolution of the less-noble metals and the surface diffusion of Pt, as well as the nature of component elements, the initial composition, the particle size and the atmosphere100. The dealloyed solid core–shell structure normally consists of an alloyed core and a pure Pt shell with a thickness of more than a few atomic layers101. According to Vegard’s law, the lattice parameters of PtM alloys fall between those of the two component metals, which means, for the dealloyed structure, a smaller PtM core is enclosed by a larger Pt shell. Thus, a compressive-strained Pt shell is expected, leading to a higher ORR activity. Indeed, previous studies confirmed that the dealloyed core–shell catalysts exhibited much higher ORR activities than the corresponding PtM alloy catalysts and state-of-the-art Pt/C (REF. 102). It was found that the surface strain in the Pt shell (and, in turn, the ORR activity) could be continuously tuned by varying the lattice mismatch at the interface, which was experimentally achieved by changing the Cu content in the precursor alloy. This electrochemically dealloyed PtCu catalyst with a solid core–shell nanostructure exhibited a fourfold increase in mass activity for the ORR compared with Pt/C (REF. 81). However, this catalyst usually shows poor long-term durability in the membrane electrode assembly test, which has been ascribed to the re-deposition of leached Cu onto the anode103.
Despite the impressive activity, electrochemical dealloying is not suitable for the large-scale synthesis of catalysts because of the limited electrode area and complicated process104. Therefore, scalable chemical dealloying or acid leaching has been used to mimic electrochemical cycling to prepare desired core–shell structured catalysts. For example, a precursor PtFe alloy catalyst was treated with 0.5 M H2SO4 to prepare the corresponding dealloyed catalyst105, on which the first evidence of lattice strain distribution within an individual core–shell nanoparticle was attained by combining aberration-corrected high-resolution transition electron microscopy and image simulations (FIG. 4a). In this study, a compressive surface strain in the Pt shell induced by the percolated lattice-contracted PtFe core was directly confirmed, which strongly supports the notion that compressive strain leads to enhanced ORR activity. Dealloyed PtNi catalysts prepared by various chemical dealloying protocols showed unprecedented ORR catalytic performance, in terms of both activity and stability, under practical fuel cell tests106 (FIG. 4b), which suggests that they may be suitable candidates for practical applications. In addition, it has also been reported that the solid core–shell structure is more stable than the nanoporous structure during operation107, because the formation of a dense Pt shell effectively prevents the leaching of less-noble metals in the core. Although the Pt shell can protect the less-noble tran sition metal atoms from dissolution under electrochemical operation, the stability of core–shell-structured catalysts is still far from satisfactory, especially when the PtM alloys are in a disordered phase. To further stabilize the less-noble metals, effort has been devoted to coating a Pt shell on an intermetallic core. For example, ordered nanocatalysts composed of an intermetallic Pt3Co core with a several-layer-thick Pt shell were prepared by simply annealing a mixture of commercial Pt/C with CoCl2 under a H2 and N2 atmosphere at 700 °C (REF. 109) (FIG. 4c). Compared with the disordered counterpart, higher compressive strain was generated on the intermetallic core supported by the Pt shell, rendering the ordered Pt3Co catalyst more active and stable. In another example, modulation of the surface strain in a PtFe–Pt core–shell structure was further achieved via a core phase transition from a disordered fcc structure to an ordered facecentred-tetragonal (fct) structure110. The ordered fct catalyst showed superior ORR catalytic performance to the disordered fcc catalyst. On the basis of quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics simulations, the activity enhancement was attributed to the release of overcompressed surface strain on the fcc-PtFe–Pt catalyst, thus optimizing the oxygen binding energy of fct-PtFe–Pt. To shift the oxygen binding energy closer to the optimal value (that is, 0.20 eV weaker than that of Pt(111)), Fe was further partially replaced by larger Cu atoms, yielding a tri metallic fct-PtFeCu core. The ordered trimetallic catalyst showed higher catalytic activity than the ordered bimetallic catalyst.
Alloying Pt with ETMs and rare-earth elements is another unique approach to enhance both the activity and stability for the ORR. This strategy was first proposed after the identification of PtSc and PtY, on the basis of DFT screening, as the most stable Pt-based bimetallic alloys111. The exceptional stability was extended to alloys of Pt with other rare-earth elements, such as Gd (REF. 112) or La (REF. 113), as they share a common characteristic: distinctively negative heats of formation. Unlike the common alloys of Pt with late transition metals, such as Fe, Co, Ni or Cu, the negative heats of formation of the Pt–ETM alloys enable the preservation of ETMs in the alloy catalysts under fuel cell operation conditions by establishing a kinetic barrier for solute metal diffusion through the alloy core and the Pt shell. Experimental measurement of the ORR activities of a number of Pt–ETM alloy catalysts in the form of either sputter-cleaned polycrystalline films114 or mass-selected gas-aggregative nanoparticles115,116 confirmed these alloys to be among the most active catalysts ever reported. The origin of the impressive ORR activity was proved to derive from a well-tuned compressive surface strain rather than from a direct electronic interaction, owing to the absence of ETMs in the first
few atomic layers117. A compressive strain was measured in a Y-modified Pt(111) single crystal under ultrahigh vacuum conditions by low-energy electron diffraction measurements117, although this contradicts our expectation: that is, rare-earth elements typically have a larger atomic radius than Pt and thus should induce tensile strain in the Pt shell. In a more recent paper, the role of lanthanide contraction in determining the behaviour of ORR electrocatalysis was demonstrated by scanning eight Pt–ETM alloys of the composition Pt5M (REF. 118). Plotting the specific activity as a function of the lattice parameter (which is proportional to the surface strain on Pt) yielded a Sabatier volcano curve (FIG. 4d), on which the most active electrocatalyst was found to be Pt5Tb, with a moderate compressive strain of 3%.
Pt‑based electrocatalysts with tensile surface strain The classic d-band model suggests that the higher tensile strain on late transition metals would result in stronger surface binding to the reaction intermediates due to an upshift of the d-band centre. As a result, the tensile strain in Pt would further facilitate the poisoning of adsorbed hydroxyl groups on the surface reactive sites, thereby slowing the overall reaction rate according to the wellestablished Sabatier principle. Indeed, this has been frequently observed in cases when a larger core, such as Au or Au-based alloys, is used to support a Pt shell99. However, recent theoretical calculations and experimental results have revealed that the d-band model prediction of tensile strain strengthening the surface binding is not universally true. In this section, we discuss two types of electrocatalytic nanomaterials with tensile strainenhanced activity: twinned and tensile-strained Pt-shell nanocatalysts.
Twinned nanocatalysts. Tailoring the shape of nanocatalysts has proved to be an efficient strategy to increase the catalytic performance of Pt-based alloys, owing not only to the exposure of desirable facets but also to the introduction of twinned boundaries119. For the typical fcc structure, twinned and non-twinned nanocrystals exhibit totally different electrocatalytic behaviour. For example, PtNi alloy nanocatalysts were shaped into icosahedra and octahedra using a gas reducing agent in a liquid-solution approach120. Although both shapes were enclosed by (111) facets, the ORR specific activity of the icosahedra was 50% higher than that of the octahedra (FIG. 5a). This difference in catalytic activity was ascribed to twin-induced differences in strain distribution on the surface. Molecular dynamics simulations revealed that the average surface strains on an icosahedron were expanded by +1.6% as a result of the presence of 30 twinned boundaries, in contrast to the non-twinned octahedron, which experienced compressive strain (FIG. 5b). Further DFT calculations confirmed a large gap in the position of the d-band centre and hydroxyl adsorption energy between the two shapes. This concept has been extended to other Pt-based nanocrystals of different compositions and morphologies121–123, further revealing the significance of twinned structure-induced strain in enhancing electrocatalytic activity.

Tensile-strained Pt shell nanocatalysts. To avoid undesirable tensile strain, most research efforts on enhancing the catalytic activity of the ORR have been devoted to combining Pt with transition metals that have a smaller atomic radius. However, not all tensile-strained Pt surfaces were reported to be deleterious to ORR activity. For example, improvement in the activity on a tensile-strained surface was observed when a monolayer of Pt was coated on a PtPb intermetallic core by galvanic displacement124. However, because the electronic interaction between the Pt monolayer and underlying Pb (that is, the ligand effect) is also significant, it is un reasonable to wholly attribute this to the strain effect. The fundamental question of how the tensile strain affects the adsorption behaviour and reactivity remains open. Recent DFT studies have shed light on this question. For example, with respect to the oxidation of CO on a strained Pt(100) surface, the tensile surface strain was calculated to lower the reaction barrier of CO oxidation by weakening the binding energy125. Another DFT study also revealed that tensile strain on the stepped surface of numerous catalytic metals resulted in a decrease in the binding strength with the reaction intermediates126. These results are in contradiction with well-established DFT predictions on the close-packed (111) facet, implying that the effect of surface strain on binding behaviour might not be universal but facet dependent.
Combining experiments with DFT calculations, we recently studied the role of tensile strain in PtPb–Pt core–shell nanoplate catalysts that possess large biaxial tensile strains on the most exposed Pt(110) facets127. The thickness of the Pt shell was approximately 1 nm (equal to four atomic layers), such that the ligand effect could be excluded (FIG. 6a–c). Even with an appreciable tensile surface strain, this nanostructure exhibited impressive specific and mass activities of 7.8 mA cm−2 and 4.3 A mg−1 for the ORR, respectively (FIG. 6d). The
nanoplate electrocatalyst also showed high stability during operation, with negligible decay in activity and no apparent structural or compositional changes after 50,000 cycles. In contrast to the conventional expectation, the DFT calculations revealed that a moderate tensile strain on the Pt(110) facet can help to decrease the Pt–O bond strength to the optimized value (FIG. 6e).

sections.heading: Pd electrocatalysts with compressive surface strain
sections.text:
Considering the great success achieved in strain-engineered Pt-based nanocatalysts, efforts have also been devoted to optimizing the surface strain for Pd-based nanomaterials, which are potential alternatives to highcost and low-abundance Pt (REFS 128,129). By controlling the composition and shell thickness, a series of monodisperse Pd-based core–shell nanocatalysts composed of a Ag or Au core and CuPd alloy shell was obtained, which showed a similar catalytic activity for the ORR as Pt-based nanocatalysts130 (FIG. 7a). On the basis of DFT calculations, it seems that the enhanced electrocatalytic activity relative to the pure Pd/C catalyst was mainly derived from an optimized surface strain on the shell (FIG. 7b). Recently, a novel colloidal chemistry approach was developed to obtain intermetallic PdCu-based nano particles (FIG. 7c) that exhibited enhanced activity and better stability for the ORR over commercial Pt/C and Pd/C catalysts131. DFT revealed the main reason for the catalytic enhancement to be the hollow sites of the intermetallic CuPd–Pd core–shell nanoparticles that are under moderate compressive strain, which can weaken the oxygen binding strength on the catalytic surface. Other reports have revealed that ordered intermetallic nanocatalysts composed of Pd3Fe (REF. 132) and PdFe (REF. 133) also show enhanced ORR activity, mainly resulting from the optimal compressive strain. sections.heading: Conclusions and perspective
sections.text:
Over the past decade, tuning the surface strain of nanocatalysts has shown great potential for boosting the electro catalytic performance of the ORR, which is the key barrier for the wide-spread application of fuel cell technology. In this Review, we have demonstrated how the electrocatalytic activity can be improved through strain engineering, including the introduction and tuning of surface strain, advanced techniques for quantifying the strain, as well as the fundamental links between surface strain, adsorption properties and reactivity. In particular, we have highlighted the latest experimental and theoretical breakthroughs that enrich our knowledge of the effects of surface strain on multimetallic materials.
Despite the remarkable progress, several key challenges remain. It seems that the classic d-band model
theory is not able to fully explain strain-induced changes in the adsorption properties and, in turn, the catalytic performance. This calls for the development of more comprehensive theoretical tools. The precise quantification of induced strain requires knowledge of the 3D positions of atoms in nanocatalysts with high accuracy, which is not easy to achieve with currently used techniques. Limited information has been gained on the in situ behaviour of strained catalytic materials, and it is still not clear if beneficial strain can be preserved during the practical electrocatalytic processes. The currently available synthesis toolbox restricts us from adjusting the surface strains of nanocatalysts. Although numerous Pt-based nano structures have been reported to show much higher ORR activities in aqueous electrolytes over commercial Pt/C, very few of them have enabled similar activity enhancements in real fuel cell tests, thus preventing a decrease in Pt loading to a sustainable level in practical applications. Compared to efforts on correlating strain and activity, much less attention has been paid to studying the influence of strain on the longterm stability, which is another key factor limiting the performance of fuel cells.

In-depth understanding of the effects of surface strain requires the accurate quantification of strain both in situ and ex situ, which requires more advanced characterization techniques. Future efforts should be devoted to optimizing the microstructure of the catalyst layer to translate the impressive ORR activity of new nanocatalysts recorded in aqueous electrolytes to practical fuel cells. metadata.abstractText: | Electrocatalysis is crucial for the development of clean and renewable energy technologies, which may reduce our reliance on fossil fuels. Multimetallic nanomaterials serve as state-of-the-art electrocatalysts as a consequence of their unique physico-chemical properties. One method of enhancing the electrocatalytic performance of multimetallic nanomaterials is to tune or control the surface strain of the nanomaterials, and tremendous progress has been made in this area in the past decade. In this Review, we summarize advances in the introduction, tuning and quantification of strain in multimetallic nanocrystals to achieve more efficient energy conversion by electrocatalysis. First, we introduce the concept of strain and its correlation with other key physico-chemical properties. Then, using the electrocatalytic reduction of oxygen as a model reaction, we discuss the underlying mechanisms behind the strain–adsorption–reactivity relationship based on combined classical theories and models. We describe how this knowledge can be harnessed to design multimetallic nanocrystals with optimized strain to increase the efficiency of oxygen reduction. In particular, we highlight the unexpectedly beneficial (and previously overlooked) role of tensile strain from multimetallic nanocrystals in improving electrocatalysis. We conclude by outlining the challenges and offering our perspectives on the research directions in this burgeoning field. By contrast, strain effects can alter the atomic spacing of surface Pt to tune the catalytic reactivity even when M atoms are buried at depths greater than 1 nm (REF. 35). Considering that M atoms on the surface or in the first few sub surface layers are easily etched away during electrochemical cycling, the role of the strain effect is more significant than the other two effects in fuel cell catalysis38. The engineering of surface strain is of growing importance for optimizing the electrocatalytic activity of fuel cell-relevant reactions. In this Review, we showcase the advances in theoretical calculations and modelling as well as experimental methods that have furthered our fundamental understanding of the effect of surface strain on electrocatalysis (FIG. 1). First, we introduce the concept of surface strain, including the quantification of surface strain in nanomaterials, as well as classic modulation and characterization approaches. Then, we review experimental and theoretical studies that correlate the electrocatalytic activity with surface strain. Next, we discuss progress in strain-engineering electrocatalysis for the ORR on Pt-based and Pd-based nanomaterials according to the types of induced surface strain (that is, compressive strain and tensile strain). Finally, challenges associated with strain-engineering electrocatalytic nanomaterials are discussed, and a perspective of future research directions is provided. Fundamental understanding of strain Definition and quantification of surface strain Elastic strain is one of the most important physical properties for solid materials and is of fundamental importance in physics39, biology40 and chemistry41. Not surprisingly, many definitions exist to describe and quantify the observed elastic strain in different applications42. For electrocatalysis, focus has been placed on materials in nanoparticulate form (for the purpose of maximizing the active surface-to-volume ratio), whereby the absolute magnitude of the induced strain is very small. In this case, strain along a line is generally defined as (lf − li)/li, where li and lf represent the atomic bond length in the initial and final states, respectively43. However, experimentally, it is notoriously challenging to evaluate the atomic bond length accurately and statistically (that is, using a large number of samples), which drives researchers to develop alternative definitions. In a given nanocrystal, strain-induced changes in the atomic bond length can be viewed as distortions of the corresponding bulk lattice. Such distortion is directly correlated with variations in the lattice parameters, which can then be readily detected by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements. Accordingly, the following equation was proposed to determine the lattice strain (s) on the surface of a catalytically active metal using an ideal core–shell structured nanoparticle as the model35: s = ((ashell – abulk)/abulk) × 100 (1) where ashell and abulk are the lattice parameters of the catalytic metal in the shell and in bulk form, respectively. Although equation 1 was initially proposed to illustrate the surface strain induced by lattice mismatch (between the surface Pt and the substrate alloy), it can be extended to other nanocrystals with surface atoms that are either compressed or expanded with respect to the ideal bulk state. This generality makes equation 1 a powerful tool for quantifying the variations in lattice strain, offering great convenience in correlating the structural properties and surface reactivity of new electrocatalytic nanomaterials. Modulation of surface strain To benefit from strain modification, the question arises of how to introduce and modulate strain to a desired level on the surface of multimetallic materials. In fact, surface strain inherently exists on nanomaterials for two main reasons. First, compared with the inner atoms, the characteristic lower coordination or dangling bonds of surface atoms (the coordination numbers for typical low-index (111) or (100) facets are 9 or 8, respectively) typically results in the emergence of internal strain in an attempt to minimize the surface energy44. Second, nanocrystals should not be simply considered as small pieces of a bulk material. Unusual forms of structural disorder may exist and thus induce surface strain45. According to these factors, the surface strain tends to compress to a larger extent on nanocrystals with a smaller size. Such size-dependence has been widely observed46,47 and is not discussed further in this Review. Although it is reasonable to tune the surface strain by controlling the size of the nanomaterial, in practical electrocatalysis, this strategy is not very useful, because it is always desirable to make electrocatalysts as small as possible to maximize the surface/volume ratio and thus the atomic utilization. Therefore, efforts have been taken to tune the surface strain without compromising other structural properties. We divide these efforts into two categories: external-force induced and architecture induced. Correlating induced strain with catalytic performance is of fundamental importance for the design and construction of highly efficient catalytic nanomaterials. Such a mechanistic study of the strain–performance relationship requires the capability of inducing surface strain on catalysts as precisely as possible, which can be achieved by exerting and controlling an external force on catalytic metals to induce the desired strain. To date, numerous approaches have been developed to tune the surface strain in catalytic materials through application of an external force, for example, by introducing subsurface inert gas (Ar or He) bubbles by low-energy inert ion bombardment48,49, physically bending or stretching the supporting substrate50,51, thermomechnically deforming a shape-memory alloy substrate52, and extracting and intercalating ions from a battery electrode support53. Depositing catalytic metals on shape or volume tunable substrates has been a powerful strategy for precisely and continuously controlling the surface strain and thus is beneficial for the fundamental study of the strain effect. A more interesting design to tune the surface strain of Pt nanoparticles from compressive to tensile was achieved using a common Li-ion battery electrode material (LiCoO2) as the support53 (FIG. 2a). LiCoO2 undergoes a large volume change when Li ions are repeatedly intercalated and extracted during electrochemical charge and discharge54,55. For a 5-nm-thick layer of Pt nanoparticles on the surface of LiCoO2 or Li0.5CoO2, compressive and tensile strains were found on Pt after the composites were subjected to charging and discharging in a battery pouch cell, respectively. Progress in nanotechnology enables many opportunities for engineering the surface strain in a number of nanomaterials by manipulating the structural properties, such as the morphology, composition and architecture. Constructing a core–shell architecture is the most common way to induce surface strain, based on lattice mismatch, in electrocatalysts56–58. When two metals or alloys with different lattice parameters are in direct contact, lattice mismatch is generated at the interface and further leads to lattice distortion (that is, lattice strain) in each crystalline component59,60 (FIG. 2b). The lattice strain effect generally decays from the interface to the surface and thus influences the electrocatalytic process by modification of both the geometric and electronic structures. Numerous synthetic approaches have been reported to produce core–shell architectures, such as epitaxial growth61–63, surface dealloying22,64–66, galvanic replacement67–69 and surface segregation70,71. Shaping nanomaterials with well-defined exposed surfaces is another way to control the surface strain. As the atoms located within the facets or at the edges or vertices of nanocrystals have very different coordination numbers, a large distribution of surface strains is expected72,73. In particular, for polycrystalline mat erials, we should consider the role of multiple twinned boundaries separating two single-crystalline domains. Decahedra and icosahedra in face-centred-cubic (fcc) structures are typical twinned morphologies, with 15 and 30 twinned boundaries, respectively. Usually, very large strains exist along the boundaries because a twinned structure does not perfectly fill the volume that the atoms would typically occupy. It is worth noting that the surface strain is also susceptible to environmental factors (such as capping ligands, adsorbates and supporting effects), making the determination of strain in practical nanomaterials much more complicated than in ideal models. Characterization techniques Conventional techniques for detecting the surface strain in nanomaterials include atomic-resolution electron microscopy, scanning tunnelling microscopy, XRD and X-ray absorption spectroscopy74. However, these methods are mainly limited to either two or three dimensions with low spatial resolution75,76. To advance our understanding of the structure–functionality relationship, it is crucial to locate the 3D position of atoms with high precision, which requires more advanced characterization techniques and modelling methods. One such technique is electron tomography77,78. Recently, using a gold nanorod as the model structure, a methodology for mapping the high-resolution 3D strain field based on compressedsensing electron tomography was demonstrated79. By introducing an additional penalty parameter to minimize the projection error, 3D reconstructed strain mapping was obtained by geometrical phase analysis (FIG. 2c), which enabled the precise determination of the atomic positions.
